pros: rigorous, professional, high-impact, and influential
cons: undergoing period of strategic transition,  with limited direction

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Based on the size of the organization I find the work itself to be stimulating and interesting, being a part of a smaller team creates opportunity to work on cool projects. The mission is inspiring although not always as easy to feel connected to in a supporting function.
cons: Executive leadership is not always visible, and lack of flexibility in RTO. Upward mobility can be a challenge based on size of organization, however, RF has strong brand name in NYC to market self for external roles.

job_title: Chief Operating Officer in New York, NY
pros: Culture, People, mission, history, headquarters
cons: Not a lot of negatives. Great place to work.

job_title: General Accounting Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: The work environment was very friendly and socially aware. You get to meet and learn a lot about the world and the many challenges the Foundation tries to overcome and make a difference in the world. Very diverse workplace environment. Good work/life balance.
cons: Slower pace environment maybe not as cutting edge in some areas but depending on your job it can be.

review_title: Smart colleagues, mission oriented, incredible brand
pros: Strong brand and legacy. Incredibly smart people with a collective focus on addressing the world’s most pressing issues.
cons: Advancement opportunities can be limited depending on the team. Internal politics can stifle progress

job_title: Senior Associate in New York, NY
pros: Mission-oriented organization where you can work with incredibly talented and dedicated colleagues
cons: Lack of transparency in HR/career progression

pros: Most everything here is great.
cons: Nothing bad to say here.

review_title: Incredible Organization with lots of potential
pros: The Rockefeller Foundation is doing tremendous work across the globe to tackle the world's biggest problems. I have never been so invigorated to be a part of and contribute to work that was so meaningful and necessary. The staff is among the best and brightest. They do a great deal to be competitive in the non-profit/foundation world.
cons: As they say with great power (and in their case resources) comes great responsibility. They have not yet done the work to become a truly equitable, inclusive and diverse workspace. HR department suffers from nepotism stunting true growth coupled with an unsustainable, unmanageable work life balance is recipe for disaster. Opportunities for growth are non-existent.

pros: Yow will be working a lot.
cons: The work is extremely rewarding.

pros:
Good working environment
Consistency 
Great benefits
cons: Upward Growth curve does take a long while

pros: Benefits, collaborative projects, decent work environment, try to accommodate its employee's needs
cons: too many meetings, cliquish, not a lot of room for position growth

pros: Excellent benefits. Smart, caring colleagues.

Keen on finding the connection between problems, root causes and solutions.

pros: Diverse culture and very inclusive

pros: Great travel perks, very generous with flights and hotels.

review_title: Wonderful place to work, great people.
pros: Exceptionally talented colleagues who live their values.

pros: Important work, great culture, flexible and empathetic throughout pandemic

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Work among the smartest people in philanthropy
cons: Can be a bit academic and philosophical as there is a demand for immense rigor before any actions are taken.

job_title: Managing Director in New York, NY
pros: Mission, vision and true caring for the individual
cons: Long hours because there is so much positive things to do

pros: Relatively flat structure, forward thinking organization with a focus on a hand full of global goals. The organization puts the wellbeing of its employees at the forefront and this has been even more apparent during Covid-19.
cons: Collaboration across global offices is a work in progress, over reliance on consultants/consulting firms (although this is improving)

job_title: Senior Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: great colleagues, intellectually stimulating, a privileged position in philanthropy
cons: slow decision making, leadership is self serving, little room for career advancement within the organization

pros: Smartest people, impact on the world, wonderful colleagues
cons: disorganized management structure, hard to advance

review_title: Inspiring organization tackling pressing global issues
job_title: Program Associate in New York, NY
pros: - Quickly gain exposure to a range of different issue areas, geographies, and intervention models - Opportunity to partner with some of the foremost thinkers and practitioners in the sector - Deep organizational commitment to impact, innovation, and embracing new ways of working  - Impressive, skilled, and supportive colleagues who are deeply passionate about the work - Opportunities to travel to regional offices and work with grantees in the field - Good comp and benefits for the social sector
cons: - Work across the Foundation's offices and with partners around the world so should be comfortable with nontraditional hours - Flat organization, promotion cycle slower than in private sector; title may not always be reflective of depth / breadth of responsibilities

pros:
Working at a foundation gives you a terrific vantage point and the ability to connect with a range of talented problem-solvers.  
Opportunity to work on important societal issues.
Salaries are competitive. 
Opportunity to work and travel internationally.
smart colleagues
cons:
RF very centralized, organized around the president.  Decisions are driven by her preferences and whims rather than by data or evidence.  
Staff generally demoralized by lack of autonomy and support.  Not a creative place.

pros: The most amazing people I have ever worked with.  Passionate, kind, thoughtful and truly do care about working to help the worlds poor and vulnerable.
cons: There is far to much focus on getting the foundation and it's president in the spotlight.  Extremely heavy focus on communications at the expense of doing work that could be truly beneficial.  A flat organization without a lot of room to grow/advance.  Promotions are given randomly and don't seem to follow any tenure or other guidelines.  You have to be given a chance to own a piece of work that top management is interested in and if you do that and shine at it, your chances of growth are much higher.

pros:
- Intelligent and supportive colleagues who represent diverse backgrounds and beliefs. An intellectually stimulating environment.
- Collaborative, collegial teams. 
- Amazing grantees; the ability to work closely with them.
- The opportunity to learn and drive interesting areas of work.
- Some flexibility and space for innovation.
cons:
- Top-down culture. 
- Highly centralized decision-making; the process for making grants and major investments is not transparent. 
- The place is being overrun by management consultants with little technical knowledge, both as hires and grant recipients. 
- Easy career advancement for some. 
- Significant resources placed on outwards communications for the purpose of sheer publicity. 
- The Foundation and its top staff being perceived positively always takes precedence over our effectiveness and impact.

review_title: Mission-driven organization with amazing history and fabulous colleagues
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Super smart, passionate, committed people. An enduring mission with an entrepreneurial approach to philanthropy.  Great springboard for next step in careers, as many of my past colleagues have moved on to amazing and far more senior roles at other organizations. Exceptional benefits, and strong compensation program.
cons: Meeting and e-mail heavy work culture, due in part to global nature of our work and also just long-standing culture. Opportunities for career advancement internally can be limited.

review_title: A very bad time for a once great organization
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Good pay and benefits
-Still a smallish core of very qualified staff
-Some very good and highly skilled grantees
-A legacy of very impressive past work
cons:
-Very top down, hierarchical management structure with very limited scope for decision making or initiative outside of a very small circle of senior leaders.  Even senior managers have very little scope to take initiative.
-Internal debate is actively discouraged.
-Any informal contact between the staff and board members appears to be forbidden.
-Not a meritocracy.  While some well qualified staff get promoted or recognized, a significant number of poorly qualified staff are also promoted.  
-Very strong focus on communications, at the expense of an effort to undertake thoughtful programming. 
-Increasing reliance on generalist management consultants, both as staff and grantees.  
-Very heavy focus on internal process, often as a substitute for deeper knowledge of specific topics.
-Consistently high turnover.

review_title: Great institution frought with poor leadership and management
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: You get to engage with intellegent, very dedicated colleagues working to solve some of the world's most pressing problems. It's an intellectually stimulating environment. Great benefits package.
cons: Decisionmaking is completely centralized, and often opaque and sometimes shows questionable judgement. Even very senior staff have little control over basic resources.  Staff morale is quite low due to a lack of career progression opportunities and an operating model that results in frequent thematic shifts.

review_title: An incredible place to have impact
pros: -Deeply talented and committed colleagues -Opportunity to work on some of the world's most important problems, and exposure to a broad range of work -Deep institutional commitment to innovation and bold thinking -Caring managers and peers -Fast pace of work and stretch opportunities at all levels
cons: -Relatively flat org structure and smaller size translates to less rapid promotion opportunities than in the private sector or the largest NGOs

review_title: Great people, challenging work, but tons to be desired (especially if you are not white)
pros:
Great and genuinely caring people
Great benefits
Work / life balance
Strong brand
cons:
No promotional track
Lacking diversity (still predominately white staff)
Shifting into a consultant / fixed term employee org.
Executive team is a who’s who list of the presidents friends (it’s public record)

job_title: IT Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great atmosphere, incredible people, and very mission oriented. The foundation provides great benefits and opportunities to network with some of the leading experts in several fields
cons: limited opportunity for career growth, few openings throughout the year and many times the opportunity to work across interdisciplinary teams are limited.

review_title: Inspiring and Great, but also limiting. Ultimately not for me.
pros: I worked with intelligent and energetic  people who were passionate about their work. The scope (globally speaking) of the work that the foundation is doing is impressive.
cons: There was not a lot of transparency from management regarding decision making. I definitely felt limited in my role.  The somewhat stiff corporate culture  felt unnecessary at times.

review_title: Amazing place for intellectual growth around global thematic issues
pros:
Ability to join global decision-making processes and work with many leading global policy actors. 
Access to influential leaders across all sectors including academia, government and private
cons: Clarity around promotions and career advancement; limited mentoring capabilities of the senior management team both due to time and depth of knowledge around particular areas of focus.

review_title: Decent work environment- no real social good
pros: Comfy work environment with subsidized food.
cons: Very stuffy and conservative. No real motivation to do social good, rather focus on media partnerships and brand recognition. Try actually improving the lives of poor and vulnerable people, you’ll have to write memos, play internal politics and pay external consultants to tell you what you already wrote in the memos.

review_title: My experience was good but the organization has changed.
job_title: Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: It was a great opportunity to work with intelligent hard working individuals on a wide range of problems.
cons: long hours and lots of soliciting from grant seekers.

pros: Smart people working on interesting projects, with an interest in innovation and big problem solving.  Great benefits and friendly atmosphere.
cons: Hierarchical, and there have been numerous complaints that it's not that easy to rise in the ranks.  Usually people leave for other organizations, then return for higher positions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The work the Foundation does is excellent and really motivating. The benefits offered are great. The work environment is beautiful. There is a real sense they value their employees.
cons: There is not a great deal of mobility but it is being addressed by the organization.

pros: Great benefits. Fantastic exposure to talented colleagues and global opportunities.
cons: Low employee morale. Limited mobility and opportunities for advancement. Lack of diversity.

pros: The Rockefeller name and legacy opens many doors and allows the foundation to be involved in making a difference across a wide range of areas.
cons: Decision making can be intransparent and feel arbitrary. Career opportunities are limited.

pros: Very friendly and comfortable working environment with nice offices and amenities.
cons: Bureaucratic and too focused on optics over impact.

review_title: Good place for the right person

pros: Pleasant work environment, great benefits, smart people, interesting work
cons: Constantly changing strategy and programs. If you are hyper flexible and willing to work on anything that comes your way, it may not feel so bad.

pros: There is a lot of work but it is always so interesting.
cons: They pay mnimum wage but at the end of the day you do learn a lot.

pros: The people are absolutely lovely and the hours and benefits are terrific.
cons: Lower salary than other industries; not a lot of opportunity for advancement

pros: Worked in an investing group with very smart people.
cons: Overall strategic objectives seemed to be shifting and deprioritizing certain areas.

review_title: I would love to work there again
pros: Lovely team. The community within Rockefeller was open, warm, and kind.
cons: Would have loved a higher salary and a longer internship than 3 months.

pros: Incredibly motivated colleagues, strong core mission that withstands time.
cons: Centralized decision-making, limited room for promotion within due to smaller size of organization, relatively formal office culture.

pros: Great place to build networks and learn about issues pretty broadly
cons: Can get overwhelming with the amount of projects and initiatives going on

pros: Many opportunities to grow and collaborate with colleagues; interesting and friendly culture.
cons: Little to no upward mobility; environment sometimes too relaxed.

pros: Great benefits, great work/life balance
